hypotheses.prediction: IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers containing 10-20 mol% cardiolipin (vs pure POPC), THEN voltage-gating midpoint shifts by 10-20 mV toward more negative potentials AND CBD Kd decreases by ≥2-fold (from ~11 µM to ≤5.5 µM).
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Reconstitute purified human VDAC1 into planar lipid bilayers (POPC alone vs POPC:CL 85:15). Measure single-channel conductance and voltage-gating curves (±60 mV triangular ramps, n≥30 insertions per condition). Determine CBD Kd via
hypotheses.expected_outcome: CL-containing bilayers show V₀ shift of −12 to −18 mV; CBD IC₅₀ for conductance inhibition drops from ~11 µM to ~4-6 µM; MST confirms Kd shift.
hypotheses.null_outcome: No significant V₀ shift (<5 mV) and CBD Kd remains 9-13 µM regardless of CL content.
controls: CL-containing bilayers without VDAC (membrane-only CBD partitioning)

hypotheses.prediction: IF VDAC1 is embedded in nanodiscs with 20 mol% cholesterol (cancer-mimetic) vs 5 mol% (healthy-mimetic), THEN the apparent CBD-VDAC1 Kd decreases from ~11 µM to 3-6 µM due to enhanced local partitioning, placing it within the 1-10 µM therapeutic window.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Assemble MSP1D1-based nanodiscs with POPC + 5 mol% or 20 mol% cholesterol, each containing single VDAC1. Measure CBD binding by MST (label VDAC1 with RED-NHS) and independently by ITC. Quantify free vs membrane-partitioned CBD using equilibrium dialysis with ³H-CBD or LC-MS/MS. Parallel SPR with VDAC1-nanodiscs immobilized on L1 chip. Timeline: 6-8 weeks.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: Apparent Kd drops 2-3 fold in 20% cholesterol nanodiscs; equilibrium dialysis confirms 2-3× higher CBD retention in cholesterol-rich nanodiscs; SPR kon increases while koff is unchanged.
hypotheses.null_outcome: Kd values within 20% of each other across cholesterol conditions; or Kd increases* in high-cholesterol nanodiscs (supporting claims [5]/[9] that cholesterol sequesters CBD away from VDAC).
controls: Empty nanodiscs (no VDAC1) for partitioning-only measurement
VDAC1 in detergent micelles (lipid-free Kd reference)

hypotheses.prediction: IF OMM cholesterol is depleted below ~15 mol% (via MβCD treatment or low-cholesterol nanodiscs), THEN olesoxime-VDAC1 binding affinity drops by ≥5-fold AND neuroprotective activity (prevention of cytochrome c release) is abolished.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: (A) Biophysical: Measure olesoxime binding to VDAC1 in nanodiscs with 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30 mol% cholesterol by MST and ITC, generating a full cholesterol-dependence curve. (B) Cellular: Treat SH-SY5Y neurons with 5 mM MβCD (titrated to achieve 40-70% cholesterol depletion, verified by Amplex Red), then challenge with staurosporine (1 µM) ± olesoxime (1-30 µM). Measure cytochrome c release (ELISA from cytosolic fraction), ΔΨm (TMRE), and viability (CellTiter-Glo). Include cholesterol repletion rescue arm. Timeline: 10-12 weeks.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: Sigmoidal cholesterol-dependence curve for olesoxime binding with inflection at ~15-20 mol%; MβCD-treated neurons show complete loss of olesoxime neuroprotection; cholesterol repletion restores protection.
hypotheses.null_outcome: Olesoxime binds VDAC1 with similar affinity (within 2-fold) regardless of cholesterol content; MβCD-treated neurons still protected by olesoxime.

hypotheses.prediction: IF CBD is delivered via liposomes matching cancer OMM composition (20 mol% cholesterol, 5 mol% CL, 75% POPC) vs generic liposomes (100% POPC), THEN IC₅₀ for cancer cell killing decreases by ≥3-fold in cancer lines (HCT116, MDA-MB-231) while remaining unchanged or increasing in normal cells (MCF10A, primary hepatocytes), with the differential being VDAC1-dependent.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Prepare liposomes by thin-film hydration + extrusion (100 nm): (i) cancer-mimetic (POPC:Chol:CL 75:20:5), (ii) healthy-mimetic (POPC:Chol:CL 90:5:5), (iii) generic (POPC only), all loaded with CBD.
